</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	categories: Knees, Hips, S.E.T., Dental, Spine &amp; CMF and Other.&nbsp;This sales analysis differs from our reportable operating segments, which are based upon our senior management
	organizational structure and how we allocate resources towards achieving operating profit goals.&nbsp;We analyze sales by
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	geography because the underlying market trends in any particular geography tend to be similar across product categories and because we primarily sell the same products in all geographies.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_8"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Net Sales by
	Geography
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following tables present net sales by geography and the components of the percentage changes (dollars in
	millions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="71%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Foreign Exchange&#148; as used in the tables in this report represents the effect of changes in
	foreign currency exchange rates on sales growth.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table presents our pro forma net sales by geography and the
	components of the percentage changes (dollars in millions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Demand (Volume and Mix) Trends
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Increased volume and changes in the mix of product sales contributed 36.7 percentage points of year-over-year sales growth during
	2015.&nbsp;Volume/mix growth was driven by the Biomet merger, new product introductions and sales in key emerging markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We believe long-term indicators point toward sustained growth driven by an aging global population, growth in emerging markets, obesity,
	proven clinical benefits, new material technologies, advances in surgical techniques and more active lifestyles, among other factors.&nbsp;In addition, demand for clinically proven premium products and patient specific devices are expected to
	continue to positively affect sales growth in markets that recognize the value of these advanced technologies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:10PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Pricing Trends
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Global selling prices had a negative effect of 2.0 percentage points on year-over-year sales during 2015.&nbsp;The negative 2.0 percent
	effect on year-over-year sales is consistent with what we have experienced over the past three years.&nbsp;The majority of countries in which we operate continued to
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	experience pricing pressure from governmental healthcare cost containment efforts and from local hospitals and health systems.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Foreign Currency Exchange Rates
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, changes in foreign currency
	exchange rates had a negative effect of 6.4 percentage points on year-over-year sales. We address currency risk through regular operating and financing activities and through the use of forward contracts and foreign currency options solely to manage
	foreign currency volatility and risk.&nbsp;Changes in foreign currency exchange rates affect sales growth, but due to offsetting gains/losses on hedge contracts and options, which are recorded in cost of products sold, the effect on net earnings in
	the near term is reduced.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Sales by Product Category
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Knees
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Knee sales increased in 2015 when compared to 2014 due to the
	Biomet merger. On a pro forma basis, Knee sales declined in 2015 due to changes in foreign currency exchange
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	25
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage26"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D112646D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	rates, the divestiture of certain product line rights and assets and continued pricing pressure. The volume/mix growth on a pro forma basis was driven by recent product introductions, such as
	Persona The Personalized Knee System.&nbsp;In particular, our EMEA and Asia Pacific operating segments experienced strong volume/mix growth in this product category.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Hips
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Hip sales increased in 2015 when compared to 2014 due to the Biomet
	merger. On a pro forma basis, positive volume and mix trends were more than offset by pricing pressure and the negative effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	S.E.T.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our S.E.T. product category sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014 due to the Biomet merger.&nbsp;On a pro forma basis, positive volume and mix trends were more than offset by pricing pressure, the
	divestiture of certain product line rights and assets and the negative effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates.&nbsp;On a pro forma basis within this category, our Extremities business achieved solid sales growth from sales of our
	shoulder and elbow products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Dental
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Dental sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014 due to the Biomet merger.&nbsp;On a pro forma basis, sales in 2015 declined partly due to a supply disruption related to a voluntary field action in
	response to a packaging issue and the negative effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates.&nbsp;We are in the process of remediating the supply disruption and we expect to do so fully by the close of the first quarter of 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Spine &amp; CMF
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Spine and CMF sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014 due to the Biomet merger.&nbsp;On a pro forma basis, strong sales of our CMF products were offset by a decline in Spine product sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table presents estimated* 2015 global market size and market share information (dollars in billions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">

	Spine &amp; CMF

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:24PX">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">

</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Current year gross margin
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	64.4
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	%&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	71.4
</FONT>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	%&nbsp;
</FONT>

	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in gross margin percentage in 2015 compared to 2014 was primarily due to increased
	inventory step-up costs as well as increased intangible asset amortization from the Biomet merger.&nbsp;The decline was also a result of lower average selling prices and higher excess and obsolete inventory charges.&nbsp;These unfavorable items were
	partially offset by higher hedge gains in 2015 from our foreign currency hedging program compared to 2014.&nbsp;Under the hedging program, for derivatives which qualify as hedges of future cash flows, the effective portion of changes in fair value
	is temporarily recorded in other comprehensive income and then recognized in cost of products sold when the hedged items affect earnings.&nbsp;Further, we experienced improved product category and geographic mix, resulting in lower average costs per
	unit sold as a percentage of sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2014, we experienced an increase in gross margin percentage compared to 2013,
	primarily due to significant excess and obsolete inventory charges related to products we
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	26
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D112646D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	intend to discontinue.&nbsp;We also recognized higher hedge gains in 2014 from our foreign currency hedging program compared to 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Operating Expenses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	R&amp;D expenses and R&amp;D as a percentage of sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014.&nbsp;The primary driver of the increased expense was the Biomet merger.&nbsp;The combination of our R&amp;D
	functions subsequent to the merger will allow us to allocate a greater portion of the combined R&amp;D spending towards innovation efforts to address unmet clinical needs and create new-market adjacencies.&nbsp;Additionally, most of our R&amp;D
	activities occur in the U.S., so expenses do not decrease proportionally to changes in net sales when there are significant changes in foreign currency exchange rates, which contributes to an increase in R&amp;D as a percentage of sales. The
	increase in 2015 reverses a trend of declines in R&amp;D expense and R&amp;D as a percentage of sales.&nbsp;In prior years, the lower spending reflected a natural decline from certain large projects that achieved commercialization, including Persona
	The Personalized Knee System, and a dedication of resources to our quality and operational excellence initiatives.&nbsp;We expect R&amp;D spending in 2016 to increase and be between 4.5 and 5.0 percent of sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	SG&amp;A as a percentage of sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014 after realizing improvements in 2014 and 2013 due to our operational
	excellence initiatives.&nbsp;The Biomet merger was the primary cause of the increase.&nbsp;We expect that SG&amp;A as a percentage of sales will continue to be higher than prior to the Biomet merger until we can realize synergy benefits of the
	merger.&nbsp;Additionally, a significant portion of our SG&amp;A expenses occur in the U.S., so expenses do not decrease proportionally to changes in net sales when there are significant changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Certain claims&#148; expense is for estimated liabilities to Durom Cup patients undergoing revision surgeries. We recorded
	additional expense of $7.7 million in 2015 for Durom Cup-related claims. Since 2008, we have recognized $479.4 million for these claims. For more information regarding these claims, see Note 20 to the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Special items&#148; have increased significantly in the past three years. The increases in 2015 were due to Biomet merger-related
	expenses such as the acceleration of unvested LVB stock options and LVB stock-based awards, retention bonuses paid to Biomet employees and third-party sales agents who remained with Biomet through the Closing Date, severance expense and contract
	terminations. &#147;Special items&#148; expense also includes our quality and operational excellence initiatives, which are intended to improve our future operating results by centralizing or outsourcing certain functions and improving quality,
	distribution, sourcing, manufacturing and our information technology systems. See Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements for more information regarding &#147;Special items&#148; charges.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Other Expense, Interest Income, Interest Expense, and Income Taxes
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other expense, net, represents debt issuance costs that we recognized for the bridge credit agreement that we entered
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	into in May 2014 in connection with the Biomet merger, the net expense related to remeasuring monetary assets and liabilities denominated in a foreign currency other than an entity&#146;s
	functional currency offset by foreign currency forward exchange contracts we enter into to mitigate any gain or loss, and the call premium expense we recognized when we repaid Biomet&#146;s senior notes, partially offset by a gain related to selling
	certain product line rights and assets. The decrease in Other expense, net in 2015 compared to 2014, was driven by fewer months of debt issuance costs from the bridge credit agreement and the gains recognized on the sale of the product line rights
	and assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net interest expense increased in 2015 due to the issuance of the debt in connection with the Biomet merger.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our effective tax rate (&#147;ETR&#148;) on earnings before income taxes for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013
	was 4.6 percent, 23.4 percent and 22.8 percent, respectively. &#147;Special items&#148; expense has significantly affected our ETR as such expenses have generally been incurred within jurisdictions with higher tax rates, resulting in lower taxable
	income in these higher tax jurisdictions. The low 2015 tax rate results from operating losses in the U.S. caused by significant expenses incurred in connection with the merger. The U.S. has a higher tax rate compared to the majority of foreign
	operations where we realized operating income. We expect &#147;Special items,&#148; the outcome of various federal, state and foreign audits, as well as expiration of certain statutes of limitations, to impact our ETR in future
	years.&nbsp;Currently, we cannot reasonably estimate the impact of these items on our financial results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Segment Operating
	Profit&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Similar to our consolidated results, our segment operating profit has been significantly
	impacted by the addition of Biomet sales and expenses to these segments. In the Americas, operating profit as a percentage of sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014, as we started to realize synergies of the merger.&nbsp;In EMEA, operating profit
	as a percentage of sales declined in 2015 compared to 2014 due to the increased Biomet expenses.&nbsp;This decline is expected to continue until we can realize the synergy benefits of the merger in this region.&nbsp;In the Asia Pacific segment,
	operating profit as a percentage of sales increased in 2015 compared to 2014 due to changes in foreign currency exchange rates and our hedging program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Non-GAAP operating performance measures
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We use financial measures that
	differ from financial measures determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (&#147;GAAP&#148;) to evaluate our operating performance. These non-GAAP financial measures exclude the impact of inventory step-up, certain other
	inventory and manufacturing related charges connected to quality enhancement and remediation efforts, &#147;Certain claims,&#148; intangible asset amortization, &#147;Special items,&#148; other expenses related to financing obtained for the Biomet
	merger, other expenses related to the call premium expense recognized to redeem the assumed Biomet senior notes, the interest expense incurred on issued debt during the period prior to the consummation of the Biomet merger and any related effects on
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">

<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	our income tax provision associated with these items and other certain tax adjustments. We use this information internally and believe it is helpful to investors because it provides useful
	period-to-period comparisons of our ongoing operating results, it helps to perform trend analysis and to better identify operating trends that may otherwise be masked or distorted by these types of items, and it provides additional transparency of
	certain items. Certain of these non-GAAP financial measures are used as metrics for our incentive compensation programs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our
	non-GAAP adjusted net earnings used for internal management purposes for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were $1,310.5 million, $1,098.0 million, and $1,069.0 million, respectively, and our non-GAAP adjusted diluted earnings per
	share were $6.90, $6.40, and $6.22, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">

<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">

</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	* The
	tax effect is calculated based upon the statutory rates for the
<BR>
	jurisdictions where the items&nbsp;were incurred.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash flows provided by operating
	activities declined to $816.7 million in 2015, compared to $1,052.8 million in 2014.&nbsp;The decreased cash flows provided by operating activities in 2015 were primarily due to higher expenses related to the Biomet merger, a $97.6 million loss on
	our forward starting interest rate swaps we settled in March 2015 when we issued senior notes for the Biomet merger and inventory investments.&nbsp;These unfavorable items were partially offset by lower tax payments and the receipt of insurance
	proceeds related to Durom Cup product liability claims in the 2015 period.&nbsp;In 2014, we made significant tax payments for certain unresolved matters in order to limit the potential impact of IRS interest charges.&nbsp;In 2016, we estimate
	operating cash flows to be in a range of $1,650.0 million to $1,750.0 million, inclusive of approximately $290.0 million of outflows related to integration expenses to drive synergies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash flows used in investing activities were $7,557.9 million in 2015 compared to $469.4 million in 2014.&nbsp;The primary investing
	activity in 2015 was the Biomet merger.&nbsp;We continued to invest in instruments for significant product launches, such as Persona The Personalized Knee System, as we deploy that system around the world.&nbsp;In 2016, we expect instrument
	investments to be in a range of $300.0 million to $325.0 million in support of our cross-sell initiatives as well as new product introductions. In 2015, we continued to invest in other property, plant and equipment at levels necessary to complete
	new product-related investments and to replace older machinery and equipment.&nbsp;In 2016, we expect to spend approximately $250.0 million on property, plant and equipment, including $105.0 million necessary to rationalize facilities and IT systems
	as well as to optimize our manufacturing and logistics network.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash flows provided by financing activities were $7,139.8
	million in 2015, compared to a use of cash of $562.4 million in 2014. We issued debt in 2015 for the Biomet merger, which resulted in proceeds and related debt issuance costs. We also repaid Biomet&#146;s senior notes that we assumed in the merger.
	Additionally, with an increase in our stock price throughout 2014, many employees exercised stock options in the prior year. Accordingly, there were fewer stock options outstanding at the end of 2014, leading to fewer option exercises in 2015
	compared to 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In February, May, July and December 2015, our Board of Directors declared cash dividends of $0.22 per
	share.&nbsp;We expect to continue paying cash dividends on a quarterly basis; however, future dividends are subject to approval of the Board of Directors and may be adjusted as business needs or market conditions change.&nbsp;As further discussed
	below, our debt facilities restrict the payment of dividends in certain circumstances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December 31, 2015, $449.5 million
	remained authorized under our $1.0 billion share repurchase program, which has no expiration date.&nbsp;In anticipation of the merger with Biomet, we suspended repurchases after the first quarter of 2014.&nbsp;We commenced share repurchases in the
	fourth quarter of 2015 and continued repurchases in the first two months of 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	28
</FONT>
</P>

	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Through February 25, 2016, we repurchased approximately $415.0 million of shares of our common stock, which includes the $250.0 million of shares that we repurchased from certain selling
	stockholders on February 10, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In order to achieve operational synergies, we expect cash outlays related to our
	integration plans to be approximately $290.0 million in 2016.&nbsp;These cash outlays are necessary to achieve our integration goals of net annual pre-tax operating profit synergies of $350.0 million by the end of the third year post-Closing Date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Also as discussed in Note 20 to our consolidated financial statements, as of December 31, 2015, a short-term liability of
	$50.0 million and long-term liability of $264.6 million related to Durom Cup product liability claims was recorded on our consolidated balance sheet. We expect to continue paying these claims over the next few years.&nbsp;We expect to be reimbursed
	a portion of these payments for product liability claims from insurance carriers.&nbsp;As of December 31, 2015, we have received a portion of the insurance proceeds we estimate we will recover.&nbsp;We have a long-term receivable of $95.3 million
	remaining for future expected reimbursements from our insurance carriers. We also had a short-term liability of $33.4 million related to Biomet metal-on-metal hip implant claims.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	At December 31, 2015, we had ten tranches of senior notes outstanding as follows (dollars in millions):
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We issued $7.65 billion of senior notes in March 2015 (the &#147;Merger Notes&#148;), the proceeds of
	which were used to finance a portion of the cash consideration payable in the Biomet merger, pay merger related fees and expenses and pay a portion of Biomet&#146;s funded debt. On June 24, 2015, we also borrowed $3.0 billion on a U.S. term loan
	(&#147;U.S. Term Loan&#148;) to fund the Biomet merger.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We may, at our option, redeem our senior notes, in whole or in part,
	at any time upon payment of the principal, any applicable make-whole premium, and accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption. In addition, the Merger Notes and the 3.375% Senior Notes due 2021 may be redeemed at our option without any
	make-whole premium at specified dates ranging from one month to six months in advance of the scheduled maturity date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have
	a $4.35 billion credit agreement (&#147;Credit Agreement&#148;) that contains: (i) a 5-year unsecured U.S. term loan facility (&#147;U.S. Term Loan Facility&#148;) in the principal amount
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	of $3.0 billion, and (ii) a 5-year unsecured multicurrency revolving facility (&#147;Multicurrency Revolving Facility&#148;) in the principal amount of $1.35 billion. The Multicurrency Revolving
	Facility will mature in May 2019, with two one-year extensions available at our option. Borrowings under the Multicurrency Revolving Facility may be used for general corporate purposes. There were no borrowings outstanding under the Multicurrency
	Revolving Facility as of December 31, 2015. The U.S. Term Loan Facility will mature in June 2020, with principal payments due beginning September 30, 2015, as follows: $75.0 million on a quarterly basis during the first three years, $112.5 million
	on a quarterly basis during the fourth year, and $412.5 million on a quarterly basis during the fifth year. In 2015, we paid $500.0 million in principal under the U.S. Term Loan Facility, resulting in $2.5 billion in outstanding borrowings as of
	December 31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We and certain of our wholly owned foreign subsidiaries are the borrowers under the Credit
	Agreement.&nbsp;Borrowings under the Credit Agreement bear interest at floating rates based upon indices determined by the currency of the borrowings plus an applicable margin determined by reference to our senior unsecured long-term credit rating,
	or at an alternate base rate, or, in the case of borrowings under the Multicurrency Revolving Facility only, at a fixed rate determined through a competitive bid process.&nbsp;The Credit Agreement contains customary affirmative and negative
	covenants and events of default for an unsecured financing arrangement, including, among other things, limitations on consolidations, mergers and sales of assets.&nbsp;Financial covenants include a consolidated indebtedness to consolidated EBITDA
	ratio of no greater than 5.0 to 1.0 through June 24, 2016 and no greater than 4.5 to 1.0 thereafter.&nbsp;If our credit rating falls below investment grade, additional restrictions would result, including restrictions on investments and payment of
	dividends.&nbsp;We were in compliance with all covenants under the Credit Agreement as of December 31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Commitments under
	the Credit Agreement are subject to certain fees.&nbsp;On the Multicurrency Revolving Facility, we pay a facility fee at a rate determined by reference to our senior unsecured long-term credit rating.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have a Japan Term Loan agreement with one of the lenders under the Credit Agreement for 11.7 billion Japanese Yen that will mature on
	May 31, 2018.&nbsp;Borrowings under the Japan Term Loan bear interest at a fixed rate of 0.61 percent per annum until maturity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We also have other available uncommitted credit facilities totaling $35.8 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We place our cash and cash equivalents in highly-rated financial institutions and limit the amount of credit exposure to any one
	entity.&nbsp;We invest only in high-quality financial instruments in accordance with our internal investment policy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of
	December 31, 2015, we had short-term and long-term investments in debt securities with a fair value of $273.1 million.&nbsp;These investments are in debt securities of many different issuers and, therefore, we believe we have no significant
	concentration of risk with a single issuer.&nbsp;All of these debt securities remain highly rated and we believe the risk of default by the issuers is low.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	29
</FONT>
</P>

<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December 31, 2015, $921.9 million of our cash and cash equivalents and short-term and
	long-term investments were held in jurisdictions outside of the U.S.&nbsp;Of this amount, $564.7 million is denominated in U.S. Dollars and, therefore, bears no foreign currency translation risk.&nbsp;The balance of these assets is denominated in
	currencies of the various countries where we operate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In light of our commitments under various credit facilities, as well as
	our expectation for continued business development, we have plans to repatriate a significant portion of our offshore earnings to the U.S.&nbsp;In particular, as a result of the Biomet merger we have unremitted foreign earnings of $4,387.9 million
	which we plan to repatriate to the U.S. in future periods.&nbsp;We have recorded a long-term liability of $1,494.9 million for the estimated tax impact of this repatriation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Management believes that cash flows from operations and available borrowings under the Multicurrency Revolving Facility are sufficient to meet our working capital, capital expenditure and debt service
	needs, as well as return cash to stockholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.&nbsp;Should additional investment opportunities arise, we believe that our earnings, balance sheet and cash flows will allow us to obtain additional
	capital, if necessary.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	$93.5 million of the other long-term liabilities on our balance sheet as of December 31, 2015 are
	liabilities related to defined benefit pension plans.&nbsp;Defined benefit plan liabilities are based upon the underfunded status of the respective plans; they are not based upon future contributions.&nbsp;Due to uncertainties regarding future plan
	asset performance, changes in interest rates and our intentions with respect to voluntary contributions, we are unable to reasonably estimate future contributions beyond 2016.&nbsp;Therefore, this table does not include any amounts related to future
	contributions to our plans.&nbsp;See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for further information on our defined benefit plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Also included in other long-term liabilities on our balance sheet are liabilities related to unrecognized tax benefits and corresponding interest and penalties thereon.&nbsp;Due to the uncertainties
	inherent in these liabilities, such as the ultimate timing and resolution of tax audits, we are unable to
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	reasonably estimate the amount or period in which potential tax payments related to these positions will be made. Therefore, this table does not include any obligations related to unrecognized
	tax benefits.&nbsp;We have also excluded long-term deferred tax liabilities from this table, as they do not represent liabilities that will be settled in cash.&nbsp;See Note 16 to our consolidated financial statements for further information on
	these tax-related accounts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have entered into various agreements that may result in future payments dependent upon various
	events such as the achievement of certain product R&amp;D milestones, sales milestones, or, at our discretion, to maintain exclusive rights to distribute a product.&nbsp;Since there is uncertainty on the timing or whether such payments will have to
	be made, we have not included them in this table.&nbsp;These payments could range from $0 to $45 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING ESTIMATES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our financial
	results are affected by the selection and application of accounting policies and methods. Significant accounting policies which require management&#146;s judgment are discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Excess Inventory and Instruments
</I>
	&#150; We must determine as of each balance sheet date how much, if any, of our inventory may
	ultimately prove to be unsaleable or unsaleable at our carrying cost.&nbsp;Similarly, we must also determine if instruments on hand will be put to productive use or remain undeployed as a result of excess supply.&nbsp;Accordingly, inventory and
	instruments are written down to their net realizable value.&nbsp;To determine the appropriate net realizable value, we evaluate current stock levels in relation to historical and expected patterns of demand for all of our products and instrument
	systems and components.&nbsp;The basis for the determination is generally the same for all inventory and instrument items and categories except for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	work&nbsp;-in-process
</FONT>
	inventory, which is recorded at
	cost.&nbsp;Obsolete or discontinued items are generally destroyed and completely written off. Management evaluates the need for changes to inventory and instruments net realizable values based on market conditions, competitive offerings and other
	factors on a regular basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
	&#150; Our income tax expense, deferred tax assets and liabilities and
	reserves for unrecognized tax benefits reflect management&#146;s best assessment of estimated future taxes to be paid. We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and numerous foreign jurisdictions. Significant judgments and estimates are required in
	determining the consolidated income tax expense.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We estimate income tax expense and income tax liabilities and assets by
	taxable jurisdiction. Realization of deferred tax assets in each taxable jurisdiction is dependent on our ability to generate future taxable income sufficient to realize the benefits. We evaluate deferred tax assets on an ongoing basis and provide
	valuation allowances unless we determine it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that the deferred tax benefit will be realized. Federal income taxes are provided on the portion of the income of foreign subsidiaries that is expected to be remitted to
	the U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	30
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D112646D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The calculation of our tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the
	application of complex tax laws and regulations in a multitude of jurisdictions across our global operations.&nbsp;We are subject to regulatory review or audit in virtually all of those jurisdictions and those reviews and audits may require extended
	periods of time to resolve. We record our income tax provisions based on our knowledge of all relevant facts and circumstances, including existing tax laws, our experience with previous settlement agreements, the status of current examinations and
	our understanding of how the tax authorities view certain relevant industry and commercial matters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We recognize tax
	liabilities in accordance with the Financial Accounting Standards Board&#146;s (&#147;FASB&#148;) guidance on income taxes and we adjust these liabilities when our judgment changes as a result of the evaluation of new information not previously
	available. Due to the complexity of some of these uncertainties, the ultimate resolution may result in a payment that is materially different from our current estimate of the tax liabilities. These differences will be reflected as increases or
	decreases to income tax expense in the period in which they are determined.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Commitments and Contingencies
</I>
	&#150;
	Accruals for product liability and other claims are established with the assistance of internal and external legal counsel based on current information and historical settlement information for claims, related legal fees and for claims incurred but
	not reported.&nbsp;We use an actuarial model to assist management in determining an appropriate level of accruals for product liability claims. Historical patterns of claim loss development over time are statistically analyzed to arrive at factors
	which are then applied to loss estimates in the actuarial model.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition to our general product liability, we have
	recorded provisions totaling $479.4 million related to the Durom Cup, including $7.7 million in 2015.&nbsp;See Note 20 to our consolidated financial statements for further discussion of the Durom Cup litigation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Goodwill and Intangible Assets
</I>
	&#150; We evaluate the carrying value of goodwill and indefinite life intangible assets annually, or
	whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&nbsp;We evaluate the carrying value of finite life intangible assets whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be
	recoverable.&nbsp;Significant assumptions are required to estimate the fair value of goodwill and intangible assets, most notably estimated future cash flows generated by these assets.&nbsp;As such, these fair value measurements use significant
	unobservable inputs.&nbsp;Changes to these assumptions could require us to record impairment charges on these assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have
	seven reporting units with goodwill assigned to them. Two of these reporting units, CMF and Bone Healing, consist entirely of assets and liabilities acquired in the Biomet merger.&nbsp;Since these assets and liabilities were valued at their
	estimated fair value on the Closing Date, in our 2015 impairment test, the carrying value approximated the fair value.&nbsp;Therefore, if these reporting units perform below what we expected at the time that we estimated their fair value, we may be
	required to record impairment charges.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our other five reporting units consist of combined Zimmer and Biomet assets and
	liabilities. In our 2015 impairment test, our EMEA reporting unit&#146;s estimated fair value only exceeded the carrying value of its net assets by 8 percent, or approximately $240 million. This reporting unit&#146;s estimated fair value has
	significantly decreased from prior year impairment tests due to the weakening of the Euro against the U.S. Dollar. For our other four reporting units, their estimated fair value exceeded their carrying value by more than 20 percent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Share-based Payment &#150;
</I>
	We measure share-based payment expense at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and
	recognize expense over the requisite service period. Determining the fair value of share-based awards at the grant date requires judgment, including estimating the expected life of stock options and the expected volatility of our stock.
	Additionally, we must estimate the amount of share-based awards that are expected to be forfeited. We estimate expected volatility based upon the implied volatility of actively traded options on our stock. The expected life of stock options and
	estimated forfeitures are based upon our employees&#146; historical exercise and forfeiture behaviors. The assumptions used in determining the grant date fair value and the expected forfeitures represent management&#146;s best estimates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	RECENT ACCOUNTING PRONOUNCEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	See Note 3 to our consolidated financial statements to see how recent accounting pronouncements have affected or may affect our financial
	position, results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_MARKET_RISK>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET_RISK"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="14%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="85%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D112646D10K_HTM_TX112646_12">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7A.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	MARKET RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are exposed to certain market
	risks as part of our ongoing business operations, including risks from changes in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices that could affect our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.&nbsp;We manage
	our exposure to these and other market risks through regular operating and financing activities and through the use of derivative financial instruments.&nbsp;We use derivative financial instruments solely as risk management tools and not for
	speculative investment purposes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	FOREIGN CURRENCY EXCHANGE RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We operate on a global basis and
	are exposed to the risk that our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be adversely affected by changes in foreign currency exchange rates.&nbsp;We are primarily exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk with respect
	to transactions and net assets denominated in Euros, Swiss Francs, Japanese Yen,
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	31
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D112646D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	British Pounds, Canadian Dollars, Australian Dollars, Korean Won, Swedish Krona, Czech Koruna, Thai Baht, Taiwan Dollars, South African Rand, Russian Rubles and Indian Rupees.&nbsp;We manage the
	foreign currency exposure centrally, on a combined basis, which allows us to net exposures and to take advantage of any natural offsets.&nbsp;To reduce the uncertainty of foreign currency exchange rate movements on transactions denominated in
	foreign currencies, we enter into derivative financial instruments in the form of foreign currency exchange forward contracts and options with major financial institutions.&nbsp;These forward contracts and options are designed to hedge anticipated
	foreign currency transactions, primarily intercompany sale and purchase transactions, for periods consistent with commitments.&nbsp;Realized and unrealized gains and losses on these contracts and options that qualify as cash flow hedges are
	temporarily recorded in other comprehensive income, then recognized in cost of products sold when the hedged item affects net earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For contracts outstanding at December 31, 2015, we had obligations to purchase U.S. Dollars and sell Euros, Japanese Yen, British Pounds, Canadian Dollars, Australian Dollars, Korean Won, Swedish Krona,
	Czech Koruna, Thai Baht, Taiwan Dollars, South African Rand, Russian Rubles and Indian Rupees and purchase Swiss Francs and sell U.S. Dollars at set maturity dates ranging from January 2016 through June 2018. The notional amounts of outstanding
	forward contracts entered into with third parties to purchase U.S. Dollars at December 31, 2015 were $1,427.5 million. The notional amounts of outstanding forward contracts entered into with third parties to purchase Swiss Francs at December 31,
	2015 were $307.2 million. The weighted average contract rates outstanding at December 31, 2015 were Euro:USD 1.21, USD:Swiss Franc: 0.91, USD:Japanese Yen 112.44, British Pound:USD 1.59, USD:Canadian Dollar 1.22, Australian Dollar:USD 0.77,
	USD:Korean Won 1,125, USD:Swedish Krona 7.68, USD:Czech Koruna 22.88, USD:Thai Baht 35.03, USD:Taiwan Dollar 31.48, USD:South African Rand 13.60, USD:Russian Ruble 65.50 and USD:Indian Ruppee 68.80.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We maintain written policies and procedures governing our risk management activities.&nbsp;Our policy requires that critical terms of
	hedging instruments be the same as hedged forecasted transactions.&nbsp;On this basis, with respect to cash flow hedges, changes in cash flows attributable to hedged transactions are generally expected to be completely offset by changes in the fair
	value of hedge instruments.&nbsp;As part of our risk management program, we also perform sensitivity analyses to assess potential changes in revenue, operating results, cash flows and financial position relating to hypothetical movements in currency
	exchange rates.&nbsp;A sensitivity analysis of changes in the fair value of foreign currency exchange forward contracts outstanding at December 31, 2015 indicated that, if the U.S. Dollar uniformly changed in value by 10&nbsp;percent relative to the
	various currencies, with no change in the interest differentials, the fair value of those contracts would increase or decrease earnings before income taxes in periods through June 2018,
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	depending on the direction of the change, by the following average approximate amounts (in millions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1.7
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Any change in the fair value of foreign currency exchange forward contracts as a result of a fluctuation
	in a currency exchange rate is expected to be largely offset by a change in the value of the hedged transaction.&nbsp;Consequently, foreign currency exchange contracts would not subject us to material risk due to exchange rate movements because
	gains and losses on these contracts offset gains and losses on the assets, liabilities and transactions being hedged.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We had
	net assets, excluding goodwill and intangible assets, in legal entities with non-U.S. Dollar functional currencies of $2,042.4 million at December 31, 2015, primarily in Euros, Japanese Yen and Australian Dollars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We enter into foreign currency forward exchange contracts with terms of one month to manage currency exposures for monetary assets and
	liabilities denominated in a currency other than an entity&#146;s functional currency. As a result, foreign currency remeasurement gains/losses recognized in earnings are generally offset with gains/losses on the foreign currency forward exchange
	contracts in the same reporting period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	COMMODITY PRICE RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We purchase raw material
	commodities such as cobalt chrome, titanium, tantalum, polymer and sterile packaging.&nbsp;We enter into supply contracts generally with terms of 12 to 24 months, where available, on these commodities to alleviate the effect of market fluctuation in
	prices.&nbsp;As part of our risk management program, we perform sensitivity analyses related to potential commodity price changes.&nbsp;A 10&nbsp;percent price change across all these commodities would not have a material effect on our consolidated
	financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	32
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D112646D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	ZIMMER BIOMET HOLDINGS, INC.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="1">
	2015 FORM 10-K ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	INTEREST RATE RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the normal course of business,
	we are exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates that could affect our results of operations and financial condition.&nbsp;We manage our exposure to interest rate risks through our regular operations and financing activities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We invest our cash and cash equivalents primarily in highly-rated corporate commercial paper and bank deposits.&nbsp;We also have
	short-term and long-term investments in highly-rated corporate debt securities, U.S. government and agency debt securities, U.S. government treasury funds, municipal bonds, foreign government debt securities, commercial paper and certificates of
	deposit.&nbsp;The primary investment objective is to ensure capital preservation of our invested principal funds.&nbsp;Currently, we do not use derivative financial instruments in our investment portfolio.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are exposed to interest rate risk on our debt obligations and our cash and cash equivalents.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have multiple fixed-to-variable interest rate swap agreements that we have designated as fair value hedges of the fixed interest rate
	obligations on our senior notes due 2019 and 2021. The total notional amounts are $250.0 million and $300.0 million for the senior notes due 2019 and 2021, respectively. On the interest rate swap agreements for the senior notes due 2019, we receive
	a fixed interest rate of 4.625 percent and pay variable interest equal to the three-month LIBOR plus an average of 133 basis points.&nbsp;On the interest rate swap agreements for the senior notes due 2021, we receive a fixed interest rate of 3.375
	percent and pay variable interest equal to the three-month LIBOR plus an average of 99 basis points.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The interest rate swap
	agreements are intended to manage our exposure to interest rate movements by converting fixed-rate debt into variable-rate debt.&nbsp;The objective of the instruments is to more closely align interest expense with interest income received on cash
	and cash equivalents.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	These derivative instruments are designated as fair value hedges under GAAP.&nbsp;Changes in the fair
	value of the derivative instrument are recorded in earnings and are offset by gains or losses on the underlying debt instrument.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based upon our overall interest rate exposure as of December 31, 2015, a change of 10&nbsp;percent in interest rates, assuming the
	principal amount outstanding remains constant, would not have a material effect on net interest expense.&nbsp;This analysis does not consider the effect of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
<B>
	CREDIT RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Financial instruments, which potentially subject us to concentrations of credit risk, are primarily cash and cash equivalents, short-term
	and long-term investments, derivative instruments, counterparty transactions and accounts receivable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We place our investments
	in highly-rated financial institutions or highly-rated debt securities and limit the
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	amount of credit exposure to any one entity.&nbsp;We believe we do not have any significant credit risk on our cash and cash equivalents and investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are exposed to credit loss if the financial institutions or counterparties issuing the debt security fail to perform. However, this
	loss is limited to the amounts, if any, by which the obligations of the counterparty to the financial instrument contract exceed our obligation.&nbsp;We also minimize exposure to credit risk by dealing with a diversified group of major financial
	institutions.&nbsp;We manage credit risk by monitoring the financial condition of our counterparties using standard credit guidelines.&nbsp;We do not anticipate any nonperformance by any of the counterparties.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our concentrations of credit risks with respect to trade accounts receivable is limited due to the large number of customers and their
	dispersion across a number of geographic areas and by frequent monitoring of the creditworthiness of the customers to whom credit is granted in the normal course of business.&nbsp;Substantially all of our trade receivables are concentrated in the
	public and private hospital and healthcare industry in the U.S. and internationally or with distributors or dealers who operate in international markets and, accordingly, are exposed to their respective business, economic and country specific
	variables.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our ability to collect accounts receivable in some countries depends in part upon the financial stability of these
	hospital and healthcare sectors and the respective countries&#146; national economic and healthcare systems. Most notably, in Europe healthcare is typically sponsored by the government. Since we sell products to public hospitals in those countries,
	we are indirectly exposed to government budget constraints. The ongoing financial uncertainties in the Euro zone impact the indirect credit exposure we have to those governments through their public hospitals. As of December 31, 2015, in Greece,
	Italy, Portugal and Spain, countries that have been widely recognized as presenting the highest risk, our gross short-term and long-term trade accounts receivable combined were $238.6 million. With allowances for doubtful accounts of $17.3 million
	recorded in those countries, the net balance was $221.3 million, representing 16 percent of our total consolidated short-term and long-term trade accounts receivable balance, net. Italy and Spain accounted for $194.2 million of that net amount. We
	are actively monitoring the situations in these countries. We maintain contact with customers in these countries on a regular basis. We continue to receive payments, albeit at a slower rate than in the past. We believe our allowance for doubtful
	accounts is adequate in these countries, as ultimately we believe the governments in these countries will be able to pay. To the extent the respective governments&#146; ability to fund their public hospital programs deteriorates, we may have to
	record significant bad debt expenses in the future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:3%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	While we are exposed to risks from the broader healthcare industry in
	Europe and around the world, there is no significant net exposure due to any individual customer. Exposure to credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, credit limits and monitoring procedures, and we believe that reserves for losses are
	adequate.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PX; FONT-SIZE:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL NARROW" SIZE="2">
	33
</FONT>
</P>
